modules.comments:
This module provides basic types and functions for dealing with colors.

Colors can be constructed from HSL values, RGB values or Hex strings /
integers. In addition, a lot of standardized named colors can be found in
`Color.Scheme.X11`.

This module also provides functions to modify colors (e.g. lighten/darken,
saturate/desaturate, complementary), to combine colors (mix) and to
analyze colors (e.g. brightness, luminance, contrast).

Implementation detail: Colors are represented by their HSL values (hue,
saturation, lightness) internally, as this provides more flexibility than
storing RGB values. In particular, note that only colors within the sRGB
gamut can be represented.

declarations.comments:
The representation of a color.

Note:
- The `Eq` instance compares two `Color`s by comparing their (integer) RGB
  values. This is different from comparing the HSL values (for example,
  HSL has many different representations of black (arbitrary hue and
  saturation values).
- Colors outside the sRGB gamut which cannot be displayed on a typical
  computer screen can not be represented by `Color`.
declarations.title: Color

declarations.comments:
Definition of a color space.

* `RGB`: red, green, blue
* `HSL`: hue, saturation, lightness
* `LCh`: Lightness, chroma, hue
* `Lab`: Lightness, a, b
declarations.title: ColorSpace

declarations.comments:
Create a `Color` from integer RGB values between 0 and 255 and a floating
point alpha value between 0.0 and 1.0.
declarations.title: rgba

declarations.comments: Create a `Color` from integer RGB values between 0 and 255.
declarations.title: rgb

declarations.comments: Create a `Color` from RGB and alpha values between 0.0 and 1.0.
declarations.title: rgba'

declarations.comments: Create a `Color` from RGB values between 0.0 and 1.0.
declarations.title: rgb'

declarations.comments:
Create a `Color` from Hue, Saturation, Lightness and Alpha values. The
Hue is given in degrees, as a `Number` between 0.0 and 360.0. Saturation,
Lightness and Alpha are numbers between 0.0 and 1.0.
declarations.title: hsla

declarations.comments:
Create a `Color` from Hue, Saturation and Lightness values. The Hue is
given in degrees, as a `Number` between 0.0 and 360.0. Both Saturation and
Lightness are numbers between 0.0 and 1.0.
declarations.title: hsl

declarations.comments:
Create a `Color` from Hue, Saturation, Value and Alpha values. The
Hue is given in degrees, as a `Number` between 0.0 and 360.0. Saturation,
Value and Alpha are numbers between 0.0 and 1.0.
declarations.title: hsva

declarations.comments:
Create a `Color` from Hue, Saturation and Value values. The Hue is
given in degrees, as a `Number` between 0.0 and 360.0. Both Saturation and
Value are numbers between 0.0 and 1.0.
declarations.title: hsv

declarations.comments:
Create a `Color` from XYZ coordinates in the CIE 1931 color space. Note
that a `Color` always represents a color in the sRGB gamut (colors that
can be represented on a typical computer screen) while the XYZ color space
is bigger. This function will tend to create fully saturated colors at the
edge of the sRGB gamut if the coordinates lie outside the sRGB range.

See:
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SRGB
declarations.title: xyz

declarations.comments:
Create a `Color` from L, a and b coordinates coordinates in the Lab color
space.
Note: See documentation for `xyz`. The same restrictions apply here.

See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space
declarations.title: lab

declarations.comments:
Create a `Color` from lightness, chroma and hue coordinates in the CIE LCh
color space. This is a cylindrical transform of the Lab color space.
Note: See documentation for `xyz`. The same restrictions apply here.

See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space
declarations.title: lch

declarations.comments:
Parse a hexadecimal RGB code of the form `#rgb` or `#rrggbb`. The `#`
character is required. Each hexadecimal digit is of the form `[0-9a-fA-F]`
(case insensitive). Returns `Nothing` if the string is in a wrong format.
declarations.title: fromHexString

declarations.comments:
Converts an integer to a color (RGB representation). `0` is black and
`0xffffff` is white. Values outside this range will be clamped.

This function is useful if you want to hard-code Hex values. For example:

``` purs
red = fromInt 0xff0000
```
declarations.title: fromInt

declarations.comments:
Convert a `Color` to its Hue, Saturation, Lightness and Alpha values. See
`hsla` for the ranges of each channel.
declarations.title: toHSLA

declarations.comments:
Convert a `Color` to its Hue, Saturation, Value and Alpha values. See
`hsva` for the ranges of each channel.
declarations.title: toHSVA

declarations.comments:
Convert a `Color` to its red, green, blue and alpha values. The RGB values
are integers in the range from 0 to 255. The alpha channel is a number
between 0.0 and 1.0.
declarations.title: toRGBA

declarations.comments:
Convert a `Color` to its red, green, blue and alpha values. All values
are numbers in the range from 0.0 to 1.0.
declarations.title: toRGBA'

declarations.comments:
Get XYZ coordinates according to the CIE 1931 color space.

See:
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SRGB
declarations.title: toXYZ

declarations.comments:
Get L, a and b coordinates according to the Lab color space.

See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space
declarations.title: toLab

declarations.comments:
Get L, C and h coordinates according to the CIE LCh color space.

See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space
declarations.title: toLCh

declarations.comments:
Return a hexadecimal representation of the color in the forms `#rrggbb`
or `#rrggbbaa`, where `rr`, `gg`, `bb`, and `aa` refer to hexadecimal
digits corresponding to the RGBA channel values between `00` and `ff`. The
alpha channel is only represented when it has a value less than 100%.
declarations.title: toHexString

declarations.comments: A CSS representation of the color in the form `hsl(..)` or `hsla(...)`.
declarations.title: cssStringHSLA

declarations.comments: A CSS representation of the color in the form `rgb(..)` or `rgba(...)`.
declarations.title: cssStringRGBA

declarations.comments: Pure black.
declarations.title: black

declarations.comments: Pure white.
declarations.title: white

declarations.comments: Create a gray tone from a lightness values (0.0 is black, 1.0 is white).
declarations.title: graytone

declarations.comments: Rotate the hue of a `Color` by a certain angle (in degrees).
declarations.title: rotateHue

declarations.comments: Get the complementary color (hue rotated by 180Â°).
declarations.title: complementary

declarations.comments:
Lighten a color by adding a certain amount (number between -1.0 and 1.0)
to the lightness channel. If the number is negative, the color is
darkened.
declarations.title: lighten

declarations.comments:
Darken a color by subtracting a certain amount (number between -1.0 and
1.0) from the lightness channel. If the number is negative, the color is
lightened.
declarations.title: darken

declarations.comments:
Increase the saturation of a color by adding a certain amount (number
between -1.0 and 1.0) to the saturation channel. If the number is
negative, the color is desaturated.
declarations.title: saturate

declarations.comments:
Decrease the saturation of a color by subtracting a certain amount (number
between -1.0 and 1.0) from the saturation channel. If the number is
negative, the color is saturated.
declarations.title: desaturate

declarations.comments:
Convert a color to a gray tone with the same perceived luminance (see
`luminance`).
declarations.title: toGray

declarations.comments:
A function that interpolates between two colors. It takes a start color,
an end color, and a ratio in the interval [0.0, 1.0]. It returns the
mixed color.
declarations.title: Interpolator

declarations.comments:
Mix two colors by linearly interpolating between them in the specified
color space. For the HSL colorspace, the shortest path is chosen along the
circle of hue values.
declarations.title: mix

declarations.comments:
Mix two colors via Dave Green's [cubehelix](http://www.mrao.cam.ac.uk/~dag/CUBEHELIX/) by
interpolating between them. Takes a gamma correction value as an argument and
returns an `Interpolator` function.

For more details see:
* [d3-plugins/cubehelix](https://github.com/d3/d3-plugins/tree/40f8b3b91e67719f58408732d7ddae94cafa559a/cubehelix#interpolateCubehelix)

Ported from:
* [d3-plugins/cubehelix/cubehelix.js](https://github.com/d3/d3-plugins/blob/40f8b3b91e67719f58408732d7ddae94cafa559a/cubehelix/cubehelix.js#L13)
declarations.title: mixCubehelix

declarations.comments:
The percieved brightness of the color (A number between 0.0 and 1.0).

See: https://www.w3.org/TR/AERT#color-contrast
declarations.title: brightness

declarations.comments:
The relative brightness of a color (normalized to 0.0 for darkest black
and 1.0 for lightest white), according to the WCAG definition.

See: https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#relativeluminancedef
declarations.title: luminance

declarations.comments:
The contrast ratio of two colors. A minimum contrast ratio of 4.5 is
recommended to ensure that text is readable on a colored background. The
contrast ratio is symmetric on both arguments:
`contrast c1 c2 == contrast c2 c1`.

See http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#contrast-ratiodef
declarations.title: contrast

declarations.comments:
Determine whether a color is perceived as a light color.

``` purs
isLight c = brightness c > 0.5
```
declarations.title: isLight

declarations.comments:
Determine whether text of one color is readable on a background of a
different color (see `contrast`). This function is symmetric in both
arguments.

``` purs
isReadable c1 c2 = contrast c1 c2 > 4.5
```
declarations.title: isReadable

declarations.comments:
Return a readable foreground text color (either `black` or `white`) for a
given background color.
declarations.title: textColor

declarations.comments:
Compute the perceived 'distance' between two colors according to the CIE76
delta-E standard. A distance below ~2.3 is not noticable.

See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_difference
declarations.title: distance

modules.name: Color

declarations.comments:
Blend two colors with a specified blend mode. The first color is the
background color, the second one is the foreground color. The resulting
alpha value is calculated as arithmetic mean.
declarations.title: blend

modules.comments:
This module defines color scales. A color scale is a continuum of colors
that is defined on the closed interval `[0, 1]`. It is defined by the two
colors at each endpoint (0 and 1) and possibly additional color stops
in between. If a color scale is sampled between two color stops, the
specified color space is used for linear interpolation (see `mix`).

declarations.comments: A point on the color scale.
declarations.title: ColorStop

declarations.comments:
Create a color stop from a given `Color` and a number between 0 and 1.
If the number is outside this range, it is clamped.
declarations.title: colorStop

declarations.comments:
A color scale is represented by a list of `ColorStops` and a `ColorSpace` that is
used for interpolation between the stops.
declarations.title: ColorScale

declarations.comments:
Create a color scale. The color space is used for interpolation between
different stops. The first `Color` defines the left end (color at ratio
0.0), the list of stops defines possible intermediate steps and the second
`Color` argument defines the right end point (color at ratio 1.0).
declarations.title: colorScale

declarations.comments:
Represents all `ColorStops` in a color scale. The first `Color` defines the left end
(color at ratio 0.0), the list of stops defines possible intermediate steps
and the second `Color` argument defines the right end point (color at ratio 1.0).
declarations.title: ColorStops

declarations.comments:
Like `combineStops`, but the width of the "transition zone" can be specified as the
first argument.

Example:

``` purs
redToBlue `combineStops epsilon x` orangeToGray
```

Here, the color at `x` will be orange and color at `x - epsilon` will be blue.
If we want the color at `x` to be blue, `combineStops' epsilon (x + epsilon)` could be used.
declarations.title: combineStops'

declarations.comments:
Concatenates two color scales. The first argument specifies the transition point as
a number between zero and one. The color right at the transition point is the first
color of the second color scale.

Example:

``` purs
redToBlue `combineStops 0.4` orangeToGray
```
declarations.title: combineStops

declarations.comments: Takes `ColorStops` and returns reverses it
declarations.title: reverseStops

declarations.comments:
Create a uniform color scale from a list of colors that will be evenly
spaced on the scale.
declarations.title: uniformScale

declarations.comments:
Create `ColorStops` from a list of colors such that they will be evenly
spaced on the scale.
declarations.title: uniformScale'

declarations.comments: Add a stop to a color scale.
declarations.title: addStop

declarations.comments: Add a stop to a list of `ColorStops`.
declarations.title: addStop'

declarations.comments:
Get the color at a specific point on the color scale by linearly
interpolating between its colors (see `mix` and `mkSimpleSampler`).
declarations.title: sample

declarations.comments:
Get the color at a specific point on the color scale, using the cubehelix
interpolation  (see `mixCubehelix` and `mkSimpleSampler`).
declarations.title: cubehelixSample

declarations.comments:
Get the color at a specific point on the color scale (number between 0 and
1). If the number is smaller than 0, the color at 0 is returned. If the
number is larger than 1, the color at 1 is returned.
declarations.title: mkSimpleSampler

declarations.comments:
A list of colors that is sampled from a color scale. The number of colors
can be specified.
declarations.title: colors

declarations.comments:
Takes a sampling function and returns a list of colors that is sampled via
that function. The number of colors can be specified.
declarations.title: colors'

declarations.comments:
Modify the color scale by applying the given function to each color stop.
The first argument is the position of the color stop.
declarations.title: modify

declarations.comments:
Modify a list of  `ColorStops` by applying the given function to each color
stop. The first argument is the position of the color stop.
declarations.title: modify'

declarations.comments: A scale of colors from black to white.
declarations.title: grayscale

declarations.comments: A color scale that represents 'hot' colors.
declarations.title: hot

declarations.comments: A color scale that represents 'cool' colors.
declarations.title: cool

declarations.comments: A spectrum of fully saturated hues (HSL color space).
declarations.title: spectrum

declarations.comments: A perceptually-uniform spectrum of all hues (LCh color space).
declarations.title: spectrumLCh

declarations.comments:
A perceptually-uniform, diverging color scale from blue to red, similar to
the ColorBrewer scale 'RdBu'.
declarations.title: blueToRed

declarations.comments:
A perceptually-uniform, multi-hue color scale from yellow to red, similar
to the ColorBrewer scale YlOrRd.
declarations.title: yellowToRed

declarations.comments:
The standard [cubehelix](http://www.mrao.cam.ac.uk/~dag/CUBEHELIX/) color
scale.
declarations.title: cubehelix

declarations.comments:
Takes number of stops `ColorStops` should contain, function to generate
missing colors and `ColorStops` itself.
declarations.title: minColorStops

declarations.comments:
A CSS representation of the color scale in the form of a comma-separated
list of color stops. This list can be used in a `linear-gradient` or
a similar construct.

Note that CSS uses the RGB space for color interpolation. Consequently, if
the color scale is in RGB mode, this is just a list of all defined color
stops.

For other color spaces, the color scale is sampled at (at least) 10
different points. This should give a reasonable approximation to the true
gradient in the specified color space.
declarations.title: cssColorStops

declarations.comments: Underling function of `cssColorStops`.
declarations.title: cssColorStopsRGB

modules.name: Color.Scale
